text:
It's great to virtually
visit Stanford. As mentioned, I actually
was a postdoc at Stanford

working with Jeff here
on data visualization. So it's great to
actually connect back.

So today I will be
sharing some of my past and also ongoing research
work in designing and building

data visualization
systems and tools. So my research group is called
Human-Data Data Interaction

Group. We are primarily interested
in designing and developing human-centered
techniques and systems

to support interactive
data analysis and also data-driven communication. So these are my
wonderful PhD students.

And we're working together
trying to actually think about how we can actually
best enable users

and machines to work together. So when a user wants to gain
some insights about a data set

or trying to communicate some
findings about a data set, they do that through
an interactive system.

And oftentimes the
user needs to convey their goals and their
intents and preferences

to the system which is
processed by the system. And in response, the system
will try to produce and generate

some visual
representations of data which needs to be interpreted
and consumed by the user.

So basically in
this kind of a loop, we have basically
this interaction

between human and machine. And Licklider back
in 1960, actually,

proposed his vision on
human-computer symbiosis which basically is about a very
tight coupling between the human

and also the machine. He anticipated that in
this collaboration model,

humans will be the ones
who are setting the goals, formulating the hypothesis,
determining the criteria,

and then performing
the evaluations. And the machine
on the other hand will do the more mundane and
potentially repetitive work.

And then together if this
symbiotic relationship actually works well, the
human and the machine

can actually produce
more effective results than either the
man or the machine

alone can actually produce. So in the real
world of-- however, in order to enable this kind
of a symbiotic relationship,

we actually face two
kinds of challenges. On one hand, oftentimes,
the visual representations

produced by the systems can
be potentially ineffective or can be very hard to
interpret by the humans.

And on the other
hand, humans sometimes have troubles or difficulties
articulating their goals,

intents, and preferences
because there is a misalignment between user's
mental models and the system's

models. So in my talk today, I
will talk about two threads of research work trying to
address these two challenges.

The first thread
is really trying to understand how we
can produce or generate

effective and interpretable
visual representations of data. And we will be looking
at this problem

in the context of visual
analysis and summarization of event sequence data. And in the second
part of my talk,

I will be talking about
how we can potentially align system model and
human mental models

in the context of authoring
and reusing data visualization designs. So let me start with
the first thread first.

So in our daily life
and work, actually, we encounter lots of
event sequence data.

So when I was working at
Adobe, the company analysts were actually interested
in understanding

how customers come
to Adobe's website and then navigate
on the website.

So every click the user
makes on the website generates a timestamp
and a page name.

So these basically are
the different attributes of an event. So as the user navigates to
different parts of the website,

all their interactions
generates a sequence of events. So this is one example
of event sequence

data in commercial domains and
these are called clickstreams.

Event sequence data are also
pervasive in many other domains. So, for example, when a
patient comes to a hospital,

they often have to go through
some kind of checkups. So this is a data set from a
pediatric trauma unit where

the patients needs to go through
the so-called A, B, C, D, D, E event checking. So airway, breathing,
circulation, et cetera.

So the doctors actually
are interested in trying to understand the
potential hidden patterns

inside these records. For example, is the procedure
actually strictly followed,

or actually, there are any kind
of deviations from the expected procedures? So, in general, we
have clickstream data,

patient records as
event sequence data, but also we have other
kinds of data sets

like human movements,
development workflows, application log data, and
also digital marketing

and touchpoints. And the tasks that
the analyst tries

to actually perform
on these data sets can also vary quite a bit. Sometimes people are
interested in trying

to identify the common
patterns in the data set. So, for example, what are
the typical navigation

paths on the website? In other cases, it's more
about detecting anomalies.

So, for example, in the
example of patient records, the doctors wants to
know do patients actually

go through essential
checks in the right order. And in other cases,
people are more interested in doing
some clustering

trying to group similar
events and sequences to identify groups of behavior.

And, of course, oftentimes in
order to answer these questions we need to visualize the data
and then explore the data.

And there are
visualizations available for us to actually apply to
these kinds of data sets.

So here we're looking
at two examples-- the Sankey diagram on top and
the icicle plot at the bottom.

So commercial tools like Google
Analytics or Adobe Analytics actually make use of
these visualizations

to show event
sequence data sets. The problem is that these
visualizations are not

very scalable. So here we're applying
the Sankey diagram to only a moderately sized data
set of clickstreams consisting

of only a dozen unique
events and only six steps and the Sankey diagram becomes
really hard to understand.

Similarly, if we're only looking
at only 200 different sequences of patients' records, the
icicle plot at the bottom

is really unintelligible. So the problem is
then how do we produce

effective and interpretable
visual representations of data? In this case, event
sequence data.

So in order to do that we
need to perform potentially data summarization
of data reduction

so that we can actually reduce
the number of visual items to be shown to the users. So we first dig into the
data mining literature

and we found a technique called
sequential data pattern mining. So here is an example.

We have five input
sequences and they're going from top to bottom. And what's sequential
pattern mining does

is that it tries to identify
a common set of events across multiple
sequences where the order

of these events in the original
sequences are preserved. So here for example we're
looking at a pattern--

e1, e2, e3, e4, e9. And they appear in all of
the five input sequences.

And similarly, we
can find other kinds of patterns which may only
happen in a subset of this data.

So here we have a
shorter pattern, and we can continue to find
more if we lower the percentage

of the sequence required. So based on this
technique, we can actually

design some
visualizations trying to help people to make
sense of their data. So here is a representation of a
pattern mined from the data set.

This shows people are actually
going through the consumer admin landing page and then they're
going to pay their bill later.

We also show the
amount of people going through each of these
milestone events in the pattern.

And then we show the individual
sequences matching this pattern as an icicle plot.

And we can highlight the
milestones of key events in the icicle plot
as shown here.

And we can also add some
additional information to show the frequency of
these individual sequences.

And with this
basic setup, we can enable people to interactively
explore the data.

So, for example, when
I click on the event, I can interactively align
these different sequences

by that event so that
I can more clearly see what is happening
before an event or in between a pair of events.

So that's like the first
iteration of the visualizations we came up with.

And what we were
doing basically is trying to follow
Ben Shneiderman's information-seeking mantra.

Overview first, zoom and filter
and then detail on demand. So here we're using this
particular visualization

as the overview. The question is, is this
an effective overview? So when we show
this to the users,

their first impression was
that, OK, there are actually 10 different sequences
or patterns which

are shown to me, which means
that there are actually 10 different groups
of behaviors, but this is a very
wrong interpretation

of the visualization. If we look at-- for example,
these three highlighted patterns here, we actually see that these
three patterns are actually

telling us about the same thing. It's about the consumer's
checkout loading page.

So we have very similar
events like checkout loaded, checkout
loading, and then

confirming order, and then
submitting order, and et cetera. So actually, there are lots
of overlapping sequences

between these three patterns. So this is actually
potentially misleading. So in order to
address this problem,

actually, we were
inspired by this idea called a branching pattern. So this is a visualization that
appeared in the visualization

arts program this
2016, where people are trying to visualize how
the different roles actually

converge to Rome. So we were actually very
inspired by this visualization because we thought, well, if
every users or every customer's

journey on a website
can be actually thought of as a physical journey,
then their navigation path may

actually differ quite a bit. But there are some commonalities
in terms of the milestone events

they come through. So can we actually design
a data mining algorithm that tries to actually pull
out these branching patterns

from a data set? And based on this idea
we came up with CoreFlow.

And this is actually
the visualization produced by CoreFlow.

It's basically showing
the same data set. We're starting with around
5,000 different visits.

We see that about 55.2%
of these customers they go

to the checkout loading page. And the y-axis encodes
the average number of steps going to that page.

So it took people
on average, 12 steps to go to the checkout
loading page.

And we see around
25% of the customers they go to the Adobe scan's
page to manage their plans.

And then for people who went
to the checkout loading page, we can see the step-by-step
process of how they actually

go through the order process. And then we also
see the gray areas.

These are the
places where people are leaving or dropping out. So we can also see
more coherent things

behaviors going on in
other parts of the website. So this visualization
basically gives us a more complete
understanding of what's

going on in people's
navigation behavior without actually any
overlapping patterns.

Under the hood, CoreFlow uses a
three-step recursive algorithm

to produce this kind
of visualization. So we first try to rank the
events, divide the sequences,

and then trim the sequences. And we do this
recursively until we reach the end of all the sequences.

So here is a very
brief illustration. So, for example, here we
have six input sequences.

And we first try to rank all
the events in these sequences by some predefined metrics.

So, for example,
here C is ranked top because it appears in the
most number of sequences

with the lowest average
index in these sequences. So we add C to the
branching pattern and then

we divide the sequences
into two groups-- those containing C and
those not containing C.

And then we trim the
sequences containing C so that we can basically
focus on the subsequences

after the first event C. So
that's the first iteration.

And then we basically do this
recursively for all the groups that have been generated because
of this process during rank,

divide, and trim again. And basically, that's how
this branching pattern

is being actually mined. So looking at these two
different visual representations

of the same data set,
I think most of us will agree that the CoreFlow
representation, the one

on the right, is actually
more effective than the one on the left. So reflecting on this
process actually,

we realized that
in order to produce interpretable visualization
and data reduction, often it

makes sense to start
with visualization design instead of starting with
the data mining algorithm.

So that's actually
the first lesson we learned from this exercise. And over the years,
actually, we see

more and more visualization
summarization techniques that came out trying to
visualize event sequence

data in many different domains. And these techniques are getting
more and more sophisticated.

So, for example, here
is a new approach trying to propose an
information-theoretic way

to summarize event
sequence data. So given the input sequences,
we try to first cluster them

into distinct clusters. And then we try to
summarize each cluster using

a sequential pattern. So, in this case
here, the main problem is trying to decide how
many clusters do we need.

And in order to
solve this problem we can use an
information-theoretic approach, where the description
length of the data set

can be defined as consisting
of the overview, which are the sequential
patterns, and then

the encoding of the raw data
based on the overview, which are the corrections of the
patterns which can lead us

to the original input data. And then based on
this formulation, the problem becomes
basically trying

to achieve a
balance or trade-off between the simplicity of the
overview and its information loss.

So we can actually
mathematically formulate the description length of any
potential visual summarization

generated using this
approach, and then we can try to come up with
optimization algorithms trying

to generate the right
number of clusters. So that's one approach. And another one is
basically trying to leverage

deep learning models like
sequence-to-sequence models. So this is a more recent
paper where the authors tries

to use an encoder and decoder
structure trying to basically summarize the probabilities of
events happening in each time

slot in a sequence. And then we can
basically visualize

these learned representations
from the data to the users. So given all these different
approaches, actually,

we see many, many potential
algorithms and tools that are available for people to
visualize their event sequence

data. Unfortunately, all these tools
produce very different results.

So here we're looking at
three visual summarization on the same data set
produced by different tools.

And they differ in terms of
the structure of the summary. Some are in the
form of sequences, some are in the form
of trees, and some

are in the form of a
directed acyclic graph. And then these summaries
also differ widely

in terms of content,
what kind of events are you included, what
are the relationships between the events, and also the
exact quantitative information.

And the granularity
of these summaries can also vary quite
a bit, which are manifested in terms of
the number of clusters

and also the number of branches. So we actually did a survey
on around 15 or so papers

that tries to propose different
ways to visually summarize this event sequence data. And we realized
that actually most

of the technique implementations
are not available. There is no way for us
to actually try them.

And all these
techniques are actually evaluated through case studies.

There are no standard evaluation
benchmarks and metrics. And oftentimes
there is also a lack

of explanations for the
performance of a technique. If summarization
actually works we

don't know why it
works that way. And if it fails to produce
a meaningful visualization we don't know why that happens.

So in order to address this
problem, my student Zinat and I, we conducted the first
comparative evaluation

of visual summarization
techniques for event sequence data. So we collected
six different data

sets in very different domains. And we identified a user task
for each of these data sets.

And then for each
data set, we try to actually analyze the
data set and come up

with some ground truth,
which are basically the main insights we
discovered from the data set.

And then we conducted
a crowdsourcing study trying to let people
decide how accurate

or how interpretable these
visual summaries are. So users are basically
presented with an insight, which

is the fact, and then they're
shown a visual summary one at a time.

So they need to
give a Likert scale rating on how well the
visualization actually represents the given
fact or the ground truth.

They also need to enter a short
explanation for their rating. So based on this study, we
found that actually there

is a trade-off between
the summary quality and also the time taken
for people to interpret the visual summaries.

So here we have three lines. Each line is a task. And then we're evaluating
three different techniques.

And you can basically see
there is like a inverse-- there is actually a correlation
between the average Likert scale

rating and the
amount of time taken to actually read those or
interpret those summaries.

We also find that
the summary quality rating depends on two factors-- content, and interpretability.

So content basically
is about the match between the visualization
pattern and the insights.

In other words, whether
important events and associated
quantitative information are actually included
in the visualization.

And in terms of
interpretability, it's really about
the effort needed to extract the information from
the visualization by the users.

So how easy it is to actually
read and also understand the visualization. And this is only
the first study.

And we're doing actually more
additional follow-up work, but this basically led us
to this new area of work

where we realize
we need to perform human-centered comparison to
evaluate these techniques.

And in order to do so, we really
need to do lots of research on the evaluation methodology,
the metrics we use,

and also potentially developing
benchmarks in terms of both data sets and also metrics for
this kind of research.

So that's the first
thread of my work, trying to produce visual
representations of event

sequence data. And we did different works in
terms of visualization designs, designing new data
mining algorithms,

and also coming up with
evaluation strategies trying to compare different techniques.

So next, I will talk
about the second thread of my work focusing on
the articulation problem,

how do we enable people
to articulate their intent effectively to the system. And we will be
talking about this

in the context of
visualization creation. So there are actually
many different tools

and very powerful tools
out there enabling people to create and express
their visualization.

So you're probably
familiar with the three or Vega-Lite or
Tableau and ggplot2.

But still, there are
potential limitations for each of these tools.

So let's take a few examples. Let's take a look
at a few examples. So here we're looking
at a stacked bar chart.

This chart basically
shows how often do politicians
tell truth or lies.

So the color indicates different
categories ranging from false

to true and different
degrees of amount of lies. And then each row
basically is a politician.

And the width of
these rectangles represents the frequency--

basically, falling
into each category. And this is a
perfectly fine chart.

But oftentimes people
would like to see how the truth and the
lies actually diverge.

So people often actually adopt a
slight variation of this design. This is called a diverging
stacked bar chart.

So basically, we try to align
these bars in the center so that it's more clearer
to see who lies more

and who actually
tells the truth more. So in order to go from
the design to the left

to the design on
the right, actually, most people's intuition
would be just trying to align these different bars
in the center by the gray area.

So that's a very
intuitive way to describe how you would actually create
the design on the right.

But this is not how many of the
visualization toolkits work.

So these toolkits often-- so for example,
this is the code you need to write to actually
create a diverging stacked bar

chart in ggplot2. In order to do this you
have to actually go back to the source data
and then change

all the data related
to the false category to negative values. And then, basically, you need
to regenerate the visualization

again, which is counterintuitive
to many people's mental models. So here is another
very simple chart.

This is a mosaic chart
or sometimes people call it a Marimekko chart.

So here we're looking
at basically different manufacturers of
computer devices,

and then different categories
of computer devices-- phone laptop, desktop. And then basically, the
proportion of each device

by a different manufacturer. So it's a very
straightforward visualization.

When we actually ask people how
they would describe or create this kind of visualization,
I think many of the people

thought describing
this visualization as some kind of slicing
and dicing a rectangle.

So you start with a
rectangle and then you slice and dice
it horizontally and vertically by manufacturer.

And then by the device
type might be an easy way to create this visualization.

However, this is not-- for
example, how Tableau works. So Zinat when she worked on the
event sequence evaluation paper

she needed to create
something like this. And she couldn't figure out
how to do that in Tableau. She had to search online and
found this 16-step tutorial

on how to create a
mosaic chart in Tableau, which is really tedious.

So, in general, I think
there is a misalignment between people's mental model
and visualization models.

And oftentimes, it's
really hard for people to articulate what
they want to a system.

And so Bostock and
Heer actually argued that many of these powerful
visualization systems

can be intimidating to novices
or they can also be inflexible.

So the abstractions used may be
actually foreign to the users. So as a result, designers
may actually often

resort to vector-based
drawing programs to realize their intent. So how do designers actually
work in vector-based drawing

tools? So here's an example. Often these tools offer
direct manipulation and offer

a what-you-see-is-what-you-get
interface. So if you move a shape
around, these dynamic guides

appear trying to let you
know if objects are aligned or how far they are
from each other.

We also see tools like Figma. So here is a feature
in Figma which allows you to basically try
to perform responsive design.

So once you set up
some constraints, then you basically
dynamically resize an object

and all the other objects will
actually respond accordingly. So can we achieve something
like this for data visualization

creation? Can people create
data visualization using a similar
interaction paradigm?

So this has been a
problem that people have been exploring for a while. So when I was at
Stanford actually,

I attended a talk by Bret
Victor where he first proposed this idea of drawing
dynamic visualizations.

And this is one of his demos. You can basically
draw these bars and populate them with data.

And then you can
directly manipulate, for example, the
text labels, map

data to the content of these
labels, changing the colors.

And you can also potentially
dynamically change the scales of these bars.

So it's a very intuitive
and also very direct

manipulation experience. When I was working
at Adobe, we also worked on something similar.

It's called Project Lincoln. Again, we were trying to
enable users to directly draw things in the canvas and
manipulate it directly and also

binding different
visual properties of these shapes to data. So when we actually presented
Lincoln at a conference,

people were actually
quite skeptical about it. So Nathan Yau, who runs
the FlowingData blog,

after he watched Lincoln
he wrote a blog post. And he basically says that
well, with data visualization,

oftentimes, you should
start with data. And then you work on
the geometry and colors and aesthetics later on.

So the data really
informs the design. And he thinks Project Lincoln
is trying to flip this workflow.

And it doesn't seem to
make much sense to him. So he's basically saying,
my brain was confused

and my gut says no. I can see why he was not very
convinced because the mainstream

approach to create
visualization oftentimes is what we know as
grammar of graphics.

So in order to create
a visualization, you start with
data, and then you

go through a number of different
stages in your process. You define the variables, the
algebra, the scales, statistics,

geometry, and so on. And in doing so, basically,
you are building up a formal specification
of what you want

the visualization to be like. And then you can pass
this formal specification to a renderer which will
compile the specification

and produce the final
visualization for you. So this is a very powerful idea. And it has been implemented
in many programming libraries

and toolkits. And it has been demonstrated
to be really expressive, able to support a wide range
of visualization designs.

It is unknown if the ideas
of direct manipulation can actually scale to many
different visualization designs.

So we were basically
interested in understanding, can we develop a similar
kind of visualization grammar

but based on the direct
manipulation paradigm? So our research question
then basically is

trying to come up
with a framework for manipulable semantic
components, which are basically

graphical objects and also
associated relationships that can be visually represented
and manipulated at design time.

And we are interested
in understanding what are the semantic components
in data visualization design

and what are the
operations to manipulate these components with data. So in order to answer
these questions,

we conducted a two-year
formative study with three different designers.

We worked with them
one hour per week, and we asked them to use
their favorite tools.

It could be Adobe
Illustrator, it could be Figma to create some
visualizations we give to them.

And based on their
workflows, we came up with around 40 different
storyboards and mockups

and we distilled this into a set
of components and operations. So I won't go into the
details of the specific

of this framework. Basically, we have
visual objects which are mark,
glyph, collection,

and reference object. And we have parametric
layout, things basically trying to position items
using some kind of automated

layout like grid layout,
stacking, and so on. We have encodings
and scales which are central to data visualization.

We also have graphical
constraints like alignment and also affixation. And then we have a
set of operations

which we define to operate
on these visual objects and also layouts. So we implemented this
framework in a library

called Mascot, standing for
Manipulable Semantic Components. And we're able to demonstrate
its expressive power

by actually producing a gallery
of diverse visualization designs.

So this work basically lays the
foundation for many applications for doing interactive
visualization.

So one application is actually
we can enable people to author visualizations
from scratch using

a what-you-see-is-what-you-get
approach. So this is implemented in a
system called Data Illustrator.

As the name suggests,
basically it's trying to adopt the paradigm of
interaction in Adobe Illustrator

but for data visualizations. So here is the interface
for Data Illustrator. We have a toolbar on the top.

So you can see we have some
of the regular drawing tools and also some of the operations
in the Mascot framework.

And then we have the
input data at the bottom. That's the CSV
data you work with.

And then in the center,
we have the canvas. So that is where you draw
shapes, you manipulate shapes,

and basically, do all
the editing you want. And on the right, we
have a layers view

which basically
shows the hierarchy of the organization of these
visual objects on the canvas.

And we also have a
property inspector panel which shows all the different
visual properties for each

of the visual objects. And you can actually perform
data binding in this panel as well.

So let's take a look at how Data
Illustrator works in action. So our goal is trying to
create a very simple pie chart

design like this. So we have two
different countries and two different
years and we want

to visualize the
household expenditure pattern in these countries
in different years.

So at the bottom right we
have the input data we have. So we have four attributes--
country, year, category,

and also percentage. In order to create
something like this in the grammar of graphics,
basically, what we need to do,

as we saw earlier, is
trying to actually write a formal specification. And here's how we can
create something similar

in Data Illustrator. So we first try to use the
circle tool to draw a circle,

and then we repeat it
by the country variable. There are two different
countries in this data set--

UK and New Zealand. And then we can keep
repeating this structure

by a different variable year. So then we can basically
get a simple grid layout. I can do some
customizations of the axis

to make the axis look nicer. And I can dynamically
change the gap

between these different
visual objects on the canvas. And then after that, we can
select any of these circles.

And then we can divide it by
the household spending variable so that gives us basically
all the pies we need,

each pie for each
expenditure category. And then we can find
the angle of the pies

and also the color of the pies
to appropriate data attributes. And in a very few
clicks, we are already

creating something similar
to the end result we want. And now we can further do
some kind of customization.

So the default color palette
doesn't seem really nice. So I can basically use
this interactive legend
to pick the color I want.

And finally, I can
do more touch-ups. So, for example, the axis here
doesn't really look really nice.

So I can-- again,
try to customize it through these property
inspector panel and also try to change
the label format as well.

So that's how you can
create visualization designs like this dynamically in
Data Illustrator in just

a few minutes. So reflecting upon
this research work,

I think one of the
lessons we learned is that we should really try to
augment and respect the users'

current practices and tools. And in order to do
this, we need to come up with a set of
primitive abstractions

which are composable
and also interpretable. So after Data Illustrator,
we continued this research

and then we were looking at more
complex data visualizations. So for example
here we're looking at a fairly complex layout
using visualization.

So this is a threemap bar chart. It's showing the import
and export revenues

by different countries. So we have all these
different bars, groups of bars corresponding
to imports and exports,

and they are arranged
by different years. And then each rectangle
here represents a country, color-coded by their continent.

So when we show this to
the potential users of Data Illustrator they
had no idea what

components or operations
they should actually use to create something like this. And this problem is not
unique to Data Illustrator.

For any kind of a
visualization library or tool, it's very hard to
actually translate

the design you want into a set
of operations or primitives afforded by that tool.

So in fact based on
our interview study with visualization designers,
we found that actually, they

rely extensively on examples for
both design ideation and also implementation.

But however they are facing
challenges in using examples, oftentimes they
don't really know

how to modify the example
to suit their own data set and needs. And oftentimes, they
face difficulties

in trying to operate and
operationalize the desired changes using specific tools.

So to address this problem we
looked into previous literature and we were actually inspired by
this idea of reusing an existing

chart. So there has been
some work that tries to actually convert
for example D2 charts

into reusable style templates. And researchers from
Microsoft Research also looked at how
we can actually

reuse infographic charts. However, these works have
their own limitations

because they mostly focus
on style, not layout. And they only support
basic chart types.

Furthermore, some
tools also assumes the examples are created
by a specific tool, which

is not very generalizable. So we are interested
in trying to understand how we can support tool-agnostic
reuse of complex layouts

in SVG charts. So SVG is a universal
vector graphics format that many tools
are actually using.

So what if we can actually
just get an SVG chart

without using its source
code and without getting its underlying data, can we
actually try to reuse the design

and apply it to
our own data set? So this year actually, the
conference is next week.

We're going to present
our work on this problem. It's called Mystique--
Deconstructing SVG

Charts for Layout Reuse. So here we are we are adopting
a human-machine collaboration

approach trying to
solve this problem. So first, we try to
preprocess an SVG example

by detecting the legend and
also the axis in a chart. And since this is not
always 100% accurate,

we let users verify the axis
and legend extraction results

and correct any mistakes
if they have to. And after that, we try to
automatically deconstruct

the main chart content into
a set of layout components based on Mascot, the Manipulable
Semantic Component frameworks.

And then users-- so
here basically, we came up with a bottom-up
hierarchical clustering

algorithm, trying to group
individual visual marks into meaningful groups
and also layouts.

And then finally, users can then
try to import their own data and specify the mappings
between these components

and also their own data. So here is a demo of
how Mystique works.

So we have imported
these treemap bar chart. And first, Mystique tries to
automatically extract the x-axis

and the y-axis and the legend. And you can see there
are some mistakes. So Mystique misses
the year labels, which

is the second level of x-axis. And also it got the type
of the y-axis wrong.

It should be numbers
instead of categories. So we offer this
interface for users to actually correct all
these different mistakes.

You can just drag
and drop these labels and then change the
data variable type.

And now here we are going
into the main interface. We're looking at the
main chart content. And then here Mystique actually
tries to analyze and decompose

the components of
the charts and then guide the user throughout
a very structured process.

So here first, Mystique
tries to highlight the first group of
rectangles and asks

the user what this highlighted
group of rectangles should represent in
their new data set. So the user have a new data set,
which is about superstore sales.

So we have all those different
order IDs, category of products, subcategory, region,
and sales figure.

So the user basically can just
choose from a dropdown menu saying this group should
be mapped to furniture.

And then Mystique basically
goes to the next step highlighting different
parts of the visualization

and asking users what data
variable in a new data set should be mapped to that
particular component.

So it goes through all these
different groupings and then also down to the level
of individual marks,

and then it goes to the-- and then it proceeds
to encodings. So it asks the user what
the height of each group

should represent and what
the color should represent. And users can just simply
choose from a dropdown menu.

And then all the visualizations
will update dynamically in real-time. So with this very
simple wizard interface,

users can reuse an existing
very complex data visualization on their own data set.

So in doing so, basically,
what Mystique does is that it tries to actually
transform the visualization

creation and authoring task
and also the skill requirement. When users are using
Mystique they no longer need

to understand all the
primitives or the components in a very complex
visualization framework,

instead, all they
need to do is just trying to specify which
part of the visualization should be mapped to which
part of the data set.

So I'd like to conclude
my talk with some quotes from Edwin Hutchins's book
Cognition in the Wild,

where he's basically
studying and talking about the nature
of cognitive tools. Data visualization for sure is
a category of cognitive tools.

And Hutchins basically
argues that tools permit us to transform
difficult tasks into ones

that can be done by
simple pattern matching, by the manipulation
of simple systems or by mental simulation
of simple systems.

Tools provide constraints on
the organization of action. By constraining the
representational states that

can be produced to ones that
are syntactically correct, it provides the
user with guidance--

as resources used in the
regulation of behavior. So in applying this argument
in the context of Mystique,

basically, we are trying to
transform the difficult task of visualization authoring
into simple actions of choosing

things from a dropdown menu. And also we are
providing constraints by actually providing this
guided wizard interface so

that users have less
chance to make mistakes, and actually, they're
having structured guidance

throughout the process. So with that, I'd like
to conclude my talk,

and thank you for
your attention.
